1610162257_191jbK3GNmVritcMymKkFuxyYFXxq.body:
The thing that terrifies me the most is how absolutely technologically illiterate most people are. I don't even consider myself at the levels of literacy necessary to want to do all that I can. But to read "not tech-savvy enough to know about or discover ZeroNet...Minds, Parler, Gab, etc." that just makes my blood boil because these things are NOT HARD TO FIND. They're right there in front of everyone's faces. But people don't want to take the time out to sit down and learn the 3 or so commands they need to get something like ZeroNet up and running... heck, my husband knows better, and it's still easier for him to tap buttons on his phone sometimes -_-

People are lambasting FB/TW/YT for the Purge, but they're just flocking to Gab, Minds, Parler, Rumble... what makes them think those platforms won't censor them in the future? We're never going to get anywhere unless people start making the jump to alternate protocols like ZeroNet, Tor, Gopher/Gemini, I2P, etc. What I would love to see is people running and hosting their own platforms from their own homes. Can't have it censored if it's all within your own control. But by the time people realize that, I'm afraid it might be too late. Looks like it already is.

> [bimmyql](#comment_6_1yhTF4WKRZsCBdVeh8fwPj14zAiEdtAXW): yeah, I did a double take there since I couldn't believe ZeroNet was considered "tech-savvy". I got it running in a few minutes. you just run the shell script and it does everything for you automatically.

I ended up taking that out of my comment, but yeah, download a tar file and extract it, run the shell script and you're good to go. One of THE easiest things I've ever accessed...

> [anshorei](#comment_171_1CgdRv2BFaVqNfmK3qGVYDuA7EDmk8dJVS): Last time I heard the rules of Parler were strict, even stricter than Twitter in some regards, but their moderation was not on a blanket "our bots will take everything down as they please as determined by arcane algorithms", but more of a "if people report it, and it does indeed violate our policies". With a such large influx of people their moderation cannot be expected to keep up. It is also likely a lot of violating posts were made in order to damage the site.

I don't think this would have made any difference. Big Tech is out to censor "alternative" media (read: the competition, We The People) no matter what. Parler could have done everything absolutely perfectly, and they STILL would have been taken offline. From what I recall, Amazon's reasoning was basically, "...mmmyeah, we don't THINK you're going to do what we want, so we'll take you out anyway."
